awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Efficient Query Processing over Large Probabilistic Knowledge Bases
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to the uncertainty, incompleteness and inconsistency from automatic extraction processes, query results from current large-scale knowledge bases (KBs) are incomplete, erroneous and conflicting. The research objective of this proposal is to extend the state-of-the-art KB systems to create a probabilistic first-order KB system that can infer missing knowledge using rules, prune conflicting knowledge using constraints, and return confidence values for resulting tuples. The new system and algorithms developed in this proposal can enable advanced online data analysis through an declarative query interface over large uncertain graphs exist in many high impact applications, including knowledge bases, social networks, and biological networks. 

The research objective of this proposal is to extend the data model, query language, query processing and optimization techniques of the state-of-the-art KB systems to support a probabilistic first-order KB system. The P.I. will design a probabilistic KB graph data model; extend SPARQL to probabilistic graph query language with additional inference operators; invent new query execution and optimization techniques for scalable inference queries; and implement a new query processing system using a unified data-parallel and graph-parallel system over web-scale probabilistic KB graphs.

For further information see the project website at: http://dsr.cise.ufl.edu/Eureka
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The P.I. proposes to study novel system and algorithmic techniques to support an efficient query processing system over large probabilistic first-order KBs that (1) captures rich probabilistic correlation, (2) enables queries involving probabilistic inference operators, and (3) supports interactive query performance.

To achieve this goal, the P.I. designs a probabilistic graph data model, extend SPARQL to
probabilistic graph query language (PGQL) with additional inference operator; invent new query execution and optimization techniques for inference queries; and implement a new query processing system using a unified data-parallel and graph-parallel system over probabilistic KB graphs.

The research direction and activities of this project in previous 4 years have resulted in significant advances in large scale statistical inference engine (Li et al, VLDB 2015; Li et al, VLDBJ 2017) and probabilistic knowledge base modeling and expansion (Chen et al, VLDB2016; Chen et al, SIGMOD 2016; Zhou et al, SIAM SDM 2019; Sadeghian et al, NeurIPS 2019). The overall Archimedes System has been published in journal papers (Zhou et al, VLDB 2016; Chen et al, ACM SIGMOD Record 2017) Additional relevant research in knowledge base construction were also conducted on multimedia knowledge base construction (Gong et al, IJCAI 2017) (Gong et al, ACM MM 2017), enhancing knowledge base with entity resolution (Grant et al, IEEE IRI 2016) and human feedback (Goldberg et al, JDIQ 2017). Further, The PI worked with a senior Ph.D. student, Ali Sadeghian on temporal link prediction using temporal knowledge graph embedding, resulting in a AAAI 2021 paper on ChronoR: Rotation Based Temporal Knowledge Graph Embedding.

This research continue to improve and maintain open source dataset, library and code repository. We continue to publish our research findings and research to advance the state-of-the-art methods for knowledge graph link prediction, rule mining and query processing. The code base and dataset of our recent work supported by this funding:

  • https://github.com/alisadeghian/DRUM

  • https://dsr.cise.ufl.edu/projects/probkb-web-scale-probabilistic-knowledge-base/

  • https://bitbucket.org/datasci/ontological-pathfinding

  • https://bitbucket.org/datasci/knowledge-expansion

I continue to mentor junior and senior students in research including undergraduates, masters and Ph.D. students. I developed, adapted and continue to fine-tune and update the data science courses for both in-person and online setting. I have been actively recruiting to increase diversity in data science research. On this research project, the PI has graduated many budding researchers over the past five years including Ali Sadeghian (2021), Miguel Rodriguez (2020), Xiaofeng Zhou (2019), Yang Peng (2018), Yang Chen (2017). In addition, this grant supported current Ph.D. students (Jayetri Bardhan, Yifan Wang and Haodi Ma) topursue their Ph.D's. Jayetrie, Yifan and Haodi Ma are all young Ph.D. students joined Fall 2019-Spring 2020. Jayetri is looking at cross-disciplinary applications of work done in this proposal, e.g., question answering over knowledge graphs connecting structured and unstructured data in healthcare domains. We are preparing a paper to submit to the ACL on a new benchmark dataset DrugEHRQA: A question answering dataset on structured and unstructured electronic health records for healthcare related queries.

We have disseminated the results from this proposal by attending top conference venues for the topic including VLDB, SIGMOD, AAAI, IJCAI, SIAM SDM and NeurIPS. We have also been submitting to top conferences and journals including SIGMOD, VLDB, NeurIPS, NAACL, AAAI, EMNLP, IJCAI, ACM RecSys, VLDBJ and ACM TODS.

The PI also worked on two research directions that are extensions to this proposed work: 1) an information retrieval and querying system that support high dimensional embedding over heterogeneous data as first class citizen; and 2) a neuro-symbolic approach to inject rules into neural deep models, such as representational learning, for link prediction over knowledge graphs.


 


Last Modified: 11/02/2021
Modified by: Daisy Zhe Wang
